div.l: And thoughte alas now comyth the flood
He set hym vp wythout wordes mo
And wyth his axe he smote the corde atwo
And downe goth all he fonde neyther to selle
Ne brede ne ale tyll he come to the selle
Vp on the flour and there aswoun he lay
¶ Vp stert her alyson and nycholay
And cryed out and harow in the strete
The neyghbours bothe smale and grete
In ronnen for to gawryn on this man
That yet a swonn laye bothe pale and wan
For wyth the falle broste hath he his arme
But stonde he must vnto his owne harme
For whan he spake he was anon bore downe
Wyth hynde nycholas and alysowne
They tolde eueri man that he was wood
So was he agast of noes flood
Thorugh fantasye that of his vanyte
He hadde boughte hym knedynge-tubbes thre
And hadde hem hanged in the roof aboue
And that he prayde hem for goddis loue
To sytten in the roof per companye
¶ The folke gan laughen at his fantasye
In to the roof they kyken and they gape
And torned all his harme in to a Iape
For what so euer this carpenter answerde
It was for nought no man his reson herde
Wyth othes grete he wasswore a doun
That he was holde wood in all the toun
For euery clerke ryght anon helde wyth other
They said þᵉ man was wood my leue brother
And euery wyght gan laugh at this stryf
¶ Thus swyued was the carpentars wyf
For all his kepynge and all his Ielowsye
And absolon hath kyssed her nether eye
And nycholas is scalded in the towte
This tale is done and god saue all the rowte
Here endyth the myllars tale

And here begynneth the reues
prologue
Whan folke had laughe at this nyce caas
Of absolon and of hynde nycholas
Dyuerse folke dyuersly they sayden
But for the more part thei lough and playden
Ne at this tale I sawe no man hym greue
But yf it were only oswolde the reue
By cause he was of carpentaris craft
A lytyll yre is in his herte there laft
He gan to grutche and blame it a lyte
¶ Sy the quod he full well I cowde the quyte
Wyth bleryng of a prowde myllars eye
Yf that me lyst to speke of rybawdrye
But I am olde me lyst not playe for aege
Gras tyme is doon my foder is now forage
This whyte top wryteth myn olde yeres
Myn hert also moulyd as myn heere is
But yet I fare as doth an open ers
For that ylke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
Tyll it be rotyn in mullok or in stre
¶ We olde men I drede so faren we
Tyll we be rotyn can we not be rype
We hoppyn alway whyle the world wold pype
For in our wyll ther stycketh euer a nayll
To haue an hoore heed and a grene tayll
As hath a leke for though our myght be gon
Our wyll desyreth foly euer in on
For whān we may nouȝt do then wol we speken
Yet in our asshen olde fyre is reken
¶ Four gledys haue we whyche I shall deuyse
Auauntynge lyenge angre and couetyse
Thyse four sparcles longeth vnto elde
Our olde lymmes mow we not be welde
But wyll ne shall not faylle that is soth
Aud yet haue I alwaye a coltys toth
As many a yere as it is passyd henne
Sen that my tappe of lyf began to renne
For sykerly whan I was born anone
Deth drewe the tappe of lyf and lete it gone
And euer syth hath so the tappe ronne
Tyll that almost all empty is the tonne
The streme of lyf now droppyth on þᵉ chymbe
The sely tonge maye well rynge and chymbe
Of wretchydnesse that past is full yore
Wyth olde folke saue dotage ther is nomore
¶ Whan þᵗat our hoste had herd this sermonyng
He gan to speken as lordly as a kynge
And sayd what amountyth all this wyt
What sholl we speke all daye of holy wryt
